sect1.title: Core options
sect1.para: These options control some of the internals of darktable.

sect4.title: memory in bytes to use for mipmap cache
sect4.para: in order to speed-up display of filmrolls, darktable stores thumbnails in a cache on disk and loads it into memory at startup; this controls the cache size in bytes; needs a restart if changed (default 536870912).

sect4.title: number of background threads
sect4.para: this controls how many parallel threads are used to create thumbnails during import; on 32bit systems it is strongly recommended to set this to 1; needs a restart if changed (default 2).

sect4.title: export multiple images in parallel
host memory limit (in MB) for tiling
sect4.para: in order to manage large images on systems with limited memory darktable does a tile-wise processing; this variable controls the maximum amount of memory (in MB) a module may use during image processing; lower values will force memory hungry modules to process image with increasing number of tiles; setting this to 0 will omit any limits; values below 500 will be treated as 500; on a 32bit system you should set this to 500; needs a restart if changed (default 1500).

sect4.title: minimum amount of memory (in MB) for a single buffer in tiling
sect4.para: if set to a positive, non-zero value this variable defines the minimum amount of memory (in MB) that darktable should take for a single tile; on a 32bit system you should set this to 8; 64bit systems can live with higher values; needs a restart if changed (default 16).

sect4.title: write sidecar file for each image
sect4.para: these redundant XMP files can later be re-imported into a different database, preserving your changes to the image; it's strongly recommended to have this option activated so you don't lose data in case of a database corruption; backing up your RAW file plus the accompanying XMP file will allow you to fully restore your work (default on).

sect4.title: activate opencl support
sect4.para: darktable can use your GPU to speed up processing significantly; interface OpenCL requires a suited hardware and matching OpenCL drivers on your system; if one of those is not found the option is greyed out; can be switched on and off at any time and takes immediate effect (default on).

sect4.title: always use littlecms2 during export
sect4.para: if this option is activated, darktable will use system library littlecms2 instead of its own routines; this is about 28x as slow as the default but might give more accurate results in some cases (default off).

sect4.title: do high quality resampling during export
sect4.para: the image will first be processed in full resolution, and downscaled at the very end. this can result in better quality sometimes, but will always be slower (default off).

sect4.title: dithering for darkroom mode
sect4.para: in darkroom mode the image in center view will be dithered by default; this adds to the latency of darktable. for some users it can be sufficient to apply dithering only when exporting images. switch this parameter to FALSE if you prefer to have a slightly faster processing speed and can accept banding artifacts on display.

sect4.title: demosaicing for zoomed out darkroom mode
sect4.para: interpolation when not viewing 1:1 in darkroom mode: "always bilinear (fast)" is fastest, but not as sharp. "at most ppg (reasonable)" is using ppg + interpolation modes specified below, "full (possibly slow)" will use exactly the settings for full-size export (default "at most ppg (reasonable)").

sect4.title: pixel interpolator
sect4.para: pixel interpolator used in rotation, lens correction, up- and downscaling; options are "bilinear", "bicubic", "lanczos2", "lanczos3" (default "lanczos3").

sect4.title: password storage backend to use
sect4.para: the storage backend for password storage; options: "none", "kwallet", "gnome keyring" (default none).

sect4.title: run indexer
sect4.para: this will index images in background, so you can search them by similarity (default off).
